Test for Differences Between Consumer Groups

Source: R/group_tests.R
test_group_differences.Rd

This function compares two groups of consumers to determine if they are statistically different. It is designed for maximum transparency during peer review, with clear documentation of every step and assumption.

Usage

test_group_differences(
  group1,
  group2,
  test_type = "auto",
  alternative = "two.sided",
  conf_level = 0.95,
  paired = FALSE,
  check_assumptions = TRUE,
  verbose = TRUE
)

Arguments

group1

A numeric vector containing data for the first group. For example, spending amounts for treatment group consumers.

group2

A numeric vector containing data for the second group. For example, spending amounts for control group consumers.

test_type

Character string specifying which test to use. Options are:

  • "t.test" - Student's t-test (assumes normal distribution)

  • "wilcoxon" - Wilcoxon rank-sum test (non-parametric)

  • "auto" - Automatically chooses based on sample size (default)

alternative

Character string specifying the alternative hypothesis. Options are "two.sided" (default), "greater", or "less".

conf_level

Numeric. Confidence level for the interval. Default is 0.95, i.e., 95 percent confidence.

paired

Logical. Are the observations paired? Default is FALSE.

check_assumptions

Logical. Should assumptions be tested? Default is TRUE. When TRUE, tests for normality and homogeneity of variance are performed and results are included in output.

verbose

Logical. Should detailed explanations be provided? Default is TRUE. When TRUE, includes verbose explanations suitable for learning.

Value

A list containing:

  • test_used: Name of the statistical test performed

  • p_value: P-value from the test

  • significant: Logical, TRUE if p < 0.05

  • group1_mean: Mean of group 1

  • group2_mean: Mean of group 2

  • group1_sd: Standard deviation of group 1

  • group2_sd: Standard deviation of group 2

  • difference: Difference between group means

  • effect_size: Cohen's d effect size

  • interpretation: Plain English interpretation of results

  • assumptions: List of assumption check results (if check_assumptions = TRUE)

  • publication_text: Publication-ready text block

  • full_test_output: Complete test results object

Details

The function performs either a t-test (for normally distributed data) or a Wilcoxon test (for non-normal data). All steps are documented and assumptions are clearly stated.

## How the Test Selection Works: When test_type = "auto" (default), the function chooses:

  • t-test if both groups have n >= 30 (Central Limit Theorem applies)

  • Wilcoxon test if either group has n < 30 (safer for small samples)

## Interpreting Results:

  • p_value < 0.05: Groups are significantly different (reject null hypothesis)

  • p_value >= 0.05: No significant difference detected (fail to reject null)

Examples

# Example 1: Compare spending between two groups
treatment_spending <- c(45.2, 67.8, 23.4, 89.1, 34.5, 56.7, 78.9, 12.3)
control_spending <- c(34.1, 45.2, 28.9, 56.3, 41.2, 38.7, 49.1, 31.4)
test_group_differences(treatment_spending, control_spending)
#> 
#> Checking statistical assumptions...
#> Warning: Autocorrelation detected in data
#> ! Lag-1 correlation = -0.446
#> ℹ This suggests observations are NOT independent
#> → Consider: Is there a time or sequence component?
#> ! Assumption checks:
#> ✖ Independence assumption may be violated
#> ✖ Homogeneity of variance assumption may be violated
#> Assumption checks complete. See 'assumptions' element in results for details.
#> Auto-selection: Using Welch's t-test (normality met, but variances unequal)
#> ============================================================================== 
#> Welch's t-test RESULTS
#> ============================================================================== 
#> 
#> SUMMARY
#> ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ 
#> • Sample size: N = 16 
#> • Alpha level: 0.05 
#> • Result: Not significant (p > 0.05 )
#> 
#> TEST STATISTICS
#> ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ 
#> • Statistic: 1.026763 
#> • Df: 8.641551 
#> • Test used: Welch's t-test 
#> • Group1 mean: 50.99 
#> • Group2 mean: 40.61 
#> • Group1 sd: 27.02 
#> • Group2 sd: 9.32 
#> • Difference: 10.38 
#> • Ci lower: -12.63 
#> • Ci upper: 33.38 
#> • Effect size: 0.51 
#> • Effect interpretation: medium 
#> • Group1 n: 8 
#> • Group2 n: 8 
#> • Full test output: 
#> Error in cat("•", field_label %+% ":", x[[field]], "\n"): argument 3 (type 'list') cannot be handled by 'cat'

# Example 2: One-sided test (is group 1 greater than group 2?)
satisfaction_a <- c(7, 8, 9, 7, 8, 9, 8, 7)
satisfaction_b <- c(5, 6, 7, 5, 6, 6, 5, 7)
test_group_differences(satisfaction_a, satisfaction_b, alternative = "greater")
#> 
#> Checking statistical assumptions...
#> Warning: Autocorrelation detected in data
#> ! Lag-1 correlation = 0.495
#> ℹ This suggests observations are NOT independent
#> → Consider: Is there a time or sequence component?
#> ! Assumption checks:
#> ✖ Independence assumption may be violated
#> ✖ Normality assumption may be violated
#> Assumption checks complete. See 'assumptions' element in results for details.
#> Auto-selection: Using Wilcoxon test (normality assumption violated)
#> Warning: cannot compute exact p-value with ties
#> ============================================================================== 
#> Wilcoxon rank-sum test RESULTS
#> ============================================================================== 
#> 
#> SUMMARY
#> ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ 
#> • Sample size: N = 16 
#> • Alpha level: 0.05 
#> • Result: Significant (p < 0.05 )
#> 
#> TEST STATISTICS
#> ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ 
#> • Statistic: 61 
#> • Df: 
#> • Test used: Wilcoxon rank-sum test 
#> • Group1 mean: 7.88 
#> • Group2 mean: 5.88 
#> • Group1 sd: 0.83 
#> • Group2 sd: 0.83 
#> • Difference: 2 
#> • Ci lower: NA 
#> • Ci upper: NA 
#> • Effect size: 2.4 
#> • Effect interpretation: large 
#> • Group1 n: 8 
#> • Group2 n: 8 
#> • Full test output: 
#> Error in cat("•", field_label %+% ":", x[[field]], "\n"): argument 3 (type 'list') cannot be handled by 'cat'

# Example 3: Paired observations (before/after measurements)
before <- c(65, 72, 68, 71, 69, 70)
after <- c(62, 68, 65, 69, 66, 67)
test_group_differences(before, after, paired = TRUE)
#> Auto-selection: Using Wilcoxon test (small sample size)
#> Warning: cannot compute exact p-value with ties
#> ============================================================================== 
#> Paired Wilcoxon test RESULTS
#> ============================================================================== 
#> 
#> SUMMARY
#> ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ 
#> • Sample size: N = 6 
#> • Alpha level: 0.05 
#> • Result: Significant (p < 0.05 )
#> 
#> TEST STATISTICS
#> ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ 
#> • Statistic: 21 
#> • Df: 
#> • Test used: Paired Wilcoxon test 
#> • Group1 mean: 69.17 
#> • Group2 mean: 66.17 
#> • Group1 sd: 2.48 
#> • Group2 sd: 2.48 
#> • Difference: 3 
#> • Ci lower: NA 
#> • Ci upper: NA 
#> • Effect size: 4.74 
#> • Effect interpretation: large 
#> • Group1 n: 6 
#> • Group2 n: 6 
#> • Full test output: 
#> Error in cat("•", field_label %+% ":", x[[field]], "\n"): argument 3 (type 'list') cannot be handled by 'cat'
